writing_prompt: After an off-world mishap leaves Daniel tangled in thorny vegetation, Jack offers his "help" with a mix of teasing and questionable grooming advice. What happens next?
story:
Glaring at his reflection in the mirror, Daniel shook his head. How had things gone so wrong? One minute they were exploring a planet, the next he was wrestling with a particularly vicious patch of thorny vegetation. And now, here he was, looking like he'd been put through a wringer. His usually neat and tidy hair was matted and tangled, leaves stuck to his face and clothes.

Just then, the door to his quarters burst open and Jack strode in, a wicked grin spreading across his face. "Well, well, well. Looks like someone had a bit of a rough time on the planet."

Daniel shot him a withering look. "Ha. Ha. Very funny, O'Neill."

Jack chuckled, sauntering over to the mirror. "I'm just trying to help, Jackson. You look like you've been put through a hedge clippers. Need a little... grooming advice, maybe?"

Daniel's eyes narrowed. "I don't think so."

But Jack just winked at him. "Oh, come on. A little bit of teasing never hurt anyone. And I'm just trying to help. After all, I've had my fair share of close calls in the field."

Daniel raised an eyebrow. "You're not exactly the poster child for ' survival skills', O'Neill."

Jack chuckled. "Hey, that's not fair. I've survived plenty of close calls. Okay, maybe not 'plenty', but a few. And I've even managed to look good doing it."

Daniel snorted. "You're not exactly known for your fashion sense, O'Neill."

Jack shrugged. "Hey, that's not the point. The point is, I'm trying to help you here. Now, let's get you cleaned up, shall we?"

Daniel sighed, but Jack was already moving in, expertly plucking leaves from his hair and clothes. As they worked, Jack chatted on, making witty remarks and teasing Daniel good-naturedly.

It was almost... soothing, Daniel realized, as Jack carefully combed out his hair and started to remove the worst of the thorns from his clothes.

Eventually, Jack stepped back, a satisfied look on his face. "There. All fixed. You look almost human again."

Daniel eyed him warily. "Thanks, I think."

But Jack just winked at him. "Anytime, Jackson. That's what friends are for."

As Daniel looked at his reflection in the mirror, he couldn't help but feel a little bit better. Maybe, just maybe, he'd gotten a bit of a lucky break, having Jack as a friend. And as for the thorny vegetation... well, that was just a minor setback.

writing_prompt: A man insists he has a solid alibi for a murder investigation but begs the detectives not to reveal it to his wife—what secret could be worth risking suspicion?
story:
Kaito sat fidgeting in his seat, avoiding eye contact with the two detectives across from him. They'd been questioning him for what felt like hours, and he was starting to get desperate. "Listen, guys, I've told you everything I can. I really don't know anything about the murder."

Ryo leaned forward, his expression stern. "Kaito, we know you were in the area around the time of the murder. Can you explain that?"

Kaito hesitated, his mind racing. He'd been in the area, all right – but not for anything sinister. In fact, it was something rather... embarrassing. He'd rather have his eyeballs removed with a spoon than admit the truth, but he couldn't think of any other way to get out of this situation.

Just as he was about to try and come up with something, Dee spoke up. "Kaito, what's going on? You're not cooperating. Is there something you're not telling us?"

Kaito took a deep breath and tried to think quickly. He couldn't reveal his secret – not even to these two detectives. "I... I just don't want to get involved in this, okay? Can't we just focus on finding the real killer?"

Ryo raised an eyebrow. "Kaito, we've been over this. We need to know what you were doing around the time of the murder. If you're hiding something from us, it's not going to help your case."

Kaito's eyes darted around the room, searching for an escape. That's when he spotted it – a golf ball perched on the edge of Ryo's desk. Inspiration struck.

"Guys, I'll tell you what I was doing. I was at the golf course, practicing my swing. I was there from... um... 2 pm to 5 pm. I'm pretty sure I was alone the whole time."

Dee's expression was skeptical. "The golf course? Really?"

Kaito nodded vigorously. "Yeah, really. I've been trying to improve my game, and I needed to practice. It's a solid alibi, right?"

Ryo's expression softened slightly. "Actually, Kaito, that does sound like a pretty solid alibi. But can you prove it?"

Kaito's heart sank. He hadn't thought of that. "Uh... well... I don't know if I can prove it, exactly. But I'm sure my golf buddies will vouch for me. I was playing with a few guys from the club."

Dee leaned back in his chair, steepling his fingers together. "Okay, Kaito. We'll look into it. But in the meantime, can you please tell your wife that we're investigating your alibi?"

Kaito's eyes widened in horror. "No way. Absolutely not. I'd rather... uh... I'd rather have my eyeballs removed with a spoon."

Ryo and Dee exchanged a look, and for a moment, Kaito thought he saw a glimmer of amusement in their eyes. "Don't worry, Kaito," Ryo said. "We'll make sure to keep your secret safe. But in the meantime, can you please go and verify your alibi with your golf buddies?"

Kaito nodded, feeling a wave of relief wash over him. It was a risk, but it was worth it to keep his secret safe. "Yeah, of course. I'll do it right now."

As he left the precinct, Kaito couldn't help but feel a sense of gratitude towards the two detectives. They'd agreed to keep his secret, and for that, he was eternally grateful.

Over the next few days, Kaito worked tirelessly to verify his alibi. He tracked down his golf buddies, who all vouched for his presence on the course at the time of the murder. He even went so far as to show up at the precinct with a video of himself playing golf, just to be extra sure.

Finally, after what felt like an eternity, Ryo and Dee gave him the all-clear. His alibi was solid, and he was in the clear.

As he walked out of the precinct, feeling a sense of relief wash over him, Kaito couldn't help but think that it was all worth it. His secret was safe, and he could finally breathe a sigh of relief.

But as he walked home, he couldn't shake the feeling that he'd just dodged a bullet. And he knew that he'd have to be careful – his secret was still out there, and he couldn't let anyone find out.

The End

writing_prompt: After a long day of chasing toddlers, cleaning up chaos, and wrangling mischievous pets, Ianto finally collapses into bed—only for Jack to come home late from work with stories of his own. How do two exhausted partners find comfort in the chaos of their shared life?
story:
Ianto let out a contented sigh as he settled into the warm bed, the duvet enveloping him like a soft cloud. After a day spent juggling tantrum-throwing toddlers, cleaning up after a mischievous cat, and refereeing fights over whose turn it was to play with the iPad, he was ready for a peaceful evening. The TV was off, the house was quiet, and the only sound was the gentle hum of the fridge in the kitchen.

He was drifting off to sleep when the front door opened, and Jack stumbled in, dripping wet and looking like he'd been put through the wringer. Ianto's eyes snapped open, and he sat up with a groan. "Long day, love?"

Jack flopped down beside him, sending the duvet flying. "You have no idea. The Hub was a nightmare today. We had a team of Weevils infiltrating the security systems, and I had to deal with a group of rogue Time Agents trying to sabotage the Cardiff Undercity project."

Ianto winced in sympathy. "Sounds like you had your hands full."

"Yeah, and to top it all off, Captain John decided to have a 'spot of fun' with the ship's computer, and now the console is singing show tunes." Jack shook his head, chuckling. "I swear, that man has a death wish."

Ianto laughed, feeling a warmth spread through his chest. "Sounds like business as usual with the Captain."

As they chatted, Ianto couldn't help but notice the dark circles under Jack's eyes. "You look like you could use a cup of tea, love," he said, sliding out of bed and padding over to the kitchen.

Jack followed him, collapsing onto a stool at the counter. "I could kill for a cup of tea right about now."

Ianto smiled, brewing a pot of strong black tea and pouring two mugs. As they sipped their tea in silence, Ianto felt his exhaustion start to seep away. Being with Jack, sharing in the chaos and mess of their life together, was what made it all worthwhile.

"Thanks, love," Jack said, reaching out to brush a strand of hair out of Ianto's face. "You always know how to make me feel better."

Ianto smiled, leaning into the touch. "That's what partners are for, isn't it?"

As they sat there together, the world outside their little bubble of domesticity receding into the background, Ianto knew that no matter what the day threw their way, they'd face it together, as a team, and as a family.

writing_prompt: After fainting at a crime scene and waking up in the ER with a stitched forehead, you realize the real challenge isn’t the injury—it’s surviving the relentless teasing from your partner, Dee, who seems to find your misfortune endlessly entertaining.
story:
Ryo was feeling embarrassed, but that was nothing new. He'd always been the type to put on a brave face, even when things were going terribly wrong. Like this morning, for instance. Fainting at a crime scene wasn't exactly the most dignified thing to do, and now he was paying the price for it.

As he sat in the emergency room, his head throbbing with a dull ache, he couldn't help but think about how this had happened. The heat of the day, the stress of the investigation, and a few hours of sleep deprivation had all combined to make him a ticking time bomb. And then, to add insult to injury, he'd tripped over his own feet and face-planted into a stack of evidence bags.

The stitches on his forehead were a testament to the ER's quick work, but they were also a constant reminder of his clumsiness. Ryo shifted uncomfortably on the hospital bed, feeling a wave of self-criticism wash over him. Why did these things always happen to him? Why couldn't he just be more careful, more competent?

He was still lost in thought when the door swung open and Dee walked in, a mischievous glint in his eye. "Well, well, well," he said, sauntering over to Ryo's bedside. "Looks like our intrepid detective has finally met his match."

Ryo's face flushed with embarrassment as Dee started to chuckle, the sound dripping with amusement. "I'm fine, Dee," he muttered, trying to brush off the teasing.

But Dee wasn't having it. "Oh, I'm shaking in my boots," he said, his voice dripping with sarcasm. "The great detective Ryo has finally fainted at a crime scene. I'm sure it has nothing to do with the fact that you're a walking disaster waiting to happen."

Ryo's eyes narrowed, but he knew better than to engage with Dee's teasing right now. Instead, he focused on his own internal monologue, trying to make sense of his feelings. Why was he so bothered by this? It wasn't like he'd never made mistakes before. But there was something about this particular incident that felt different, like it was a reflection of his own inadequacies.

As the minutes ticked by, Dee continued to poke fun at Ryo's misfortune, but Ryo barely registered it. He was too busy wrestling with his own emotions, trying to come to terms with his own vulnerabilities. It wasn't until Dee leaned in and gently brushed a strand of hair out of Ryo's face that he finally felt a spark of defensiveness.

"Hey, watch it," Ryo said, his voice low and even.

Dee's eyes met his, and for a moment, they just stared at each other. Then, to Ryo's surprise, Dee's expression softened, and he reached out to take Ryo's hand. "I'm sorry, okay? I know you're not a walking disaster. You're just... accident-prone, that's all."

Ryo's face still flushed with embarrassment, but he felt a wave of gratitude wash over him. Maybe, just maybe, he wasn't alone in this after all. And who knows, maybe he'd even learn to laugh at himself. But for now, he was just happy to have Dee by his side, teasing him mercilessly and making him feel like a normal human being.

writing_prompt: On a planet with low gravity, your team struggles to stay grounded—literally—while navigating the strange terrain. But the real challenge begins when you discover you're not the only ones bouncing around.
story:
The ramp leading to the surface of the alien planet stretched out before them like a gleaming white ribbon. Jack O'Neill, ever the pragmatist, took a deep breath, adjusted his pack, and stepped forward, his boots making barely a sound in the low-gravity environment.

"Gravity's about 20% of Earth's," Daniel Jackson whispered, hovering beside him. "We should be able to move around pretty easily."

"Easy?" Carter's voice was laced with excitement as she floated down the ramp, her eyes shining. "This is incredible!"

Teal'c, ever the pragmatist, simply nodded, his face expressionless as he descended with a deliberate, calculated pace, his knees bent to reduce the rebound effect.

As the team made their way across the alien landscape, they found themselves bouncing around like children in a playground. O'Neill, ever the humorist, chuckled as he watched Carter do an unintentional loop-the-loop, her hair flying out behind her like a golden banner.

"Stop bouncing around like a damn kangaroo and get back here!" he called out, trying to keep a straight face.

Daniel, meanwhile, was having the time of his life, leaping from rock to rock with an ease that belied the low gravity.

"Whoa, this is amazing!" he exclaimed, bounding over to a cluster of peculiar, glowing plants. "Look at these, Jack! They're some sort of energy source, I'm sure of it!"

Carter, meanwhile, was busy studying the local flora, her eyes scanning the terrain with a scientist's intensity.

As they explored, the team stumbled upon a strange, alien structure in the distance. It was a series of interconnected domes, each one pulsating with a soft, blue light.

"I think we should investigate," Carter said, her voice full of excitement.

O'Neill nodded, his eyes narrowing as he led the team towards the structure.

As they approached, they noticed something strange. The alien inhabitants of the planet were also bouncing around, their movements eerily similar to the team's own.

"Looks like we're not the only ones who can't stay grounded," O'Neill observed dryly.

Daniel's eyes widened as he watched a group of aliens doing a sort of low-gravity dance, their movements fluid and almost... enjoyable.

"This is incredible," he breathed. "The low gravity must be affecting their entire culture."

Carter, meanwhile, was busy scanning the area with her tricorder, her face set in concentration.

"I'm reading some sort of energy signature coming from the structure," she said, her voice tight with excitement. "I think it might be connected to the low gravity."

O'Neill's eyes locked onto hers, a spark of understanding passing between them.

"Let's go take a closer look," he said, his voice low and steady.

As they approached the structure, the aliens began to converge on them, their movements still eerily similar to the team's own.

"Well, this is a first," O'Neill muttered, his eyes scanning the alien crowd.

Teal'c, meanwhile, simply stood tall, his face expressionless as he watched the aliens approach.

"We should be prepared for anything," he said, his voice low and calm.

The team exchanged a look, their faces set with determination.

They were ready for whatever came next.
